trial_identification.studytitle: Intervention to improve quality use of medicines in elderly people: effect on health outcomes.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effectiveness of an educational Quality Use of Medicines Program on medicines use, falls and quality of life for patients aged 65 years and over in general practice.

conditions.healthcondition: Quality Use of Medicines issues (polypharmacy/ medication errors/ drug interactions/ Prescriptions, Drug/ Self Medication)

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Research that is not of generic health relevance and not applicable to specific health categories listed above

interventions.interventions: Intervention: 1) Academic detailing ( two long consultations, three to four weeks apart ). 2) Medication Risk Assessment Form (individualised patient feedback to GP - time frame depending on number of older patients seen in the general practice). 3) Prescribing information. 4) Medication review (standard or long consultation). 5) Prescribing feedback (one time). 6) Financial incentives.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Use of thiazide diuretics, NSAIDs and benzodiazepines

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At four and 12 month follow up
At four and 12 month follow up
At four and 12 month follow up

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Eligible practitioners were those who had been based at their current practice for 12 months or more. Patients were eligible if they were aged 65 or more, not living in a nursing home, and not too ill or infirm at the time of their consultation.

trial_design.concealment: Computerised generated random number allocation. Assignment took place after GPs sent back their consent form. The sequence was not concealed from the research coordinator who needed to operationalise the intervention for doctors in the intervention group. It was also not possible to conceal the treatment allocation from the GPs. Patients, general practice office staff who recruited the patients, data collectors (outcome assessors), and data managers were unaware of treatment allocation.
trial_design.sequence: A statistician from another location within the university wrote a computer random-number generator in SAS. Cluster randomisation at practice level.
